Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 06:39PM determinedmom wrote: I found my first moveable lump at age 18 and finally had it biopsied at age 28, fibroadenoma. Had another palpable moveable lump that I found again around age 39, also fibroadenoma. My cancer didn't come except for on mammogram as microcalcifications, no palpable mass. It is my understanding that it being moveable is good sign. However, it's best to get a professional opinion. When you say you applied for insurance, is it individual or group policy? If it's individual they usually have a rider (which means they won't pay) for any pre-existing condition for a certain amount of time, however, grp has to cover effective immediately, at least here in FL. I would prefer you not wait to see a MD, is there a free clinic near by? If you do wait and you have individual coverage, perhaps don't mention when you found it. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: 24 with lump in right breast. wolfwonderess determinedmom

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2007 11:20PM determinedmom wrote:
Posts.Title: Diagnosed two weeks ago Urbie determinedmom

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 02:45PM determinedmom wrote: If my mom was diagnosed and not me, I'm not sure which would be worst. It sounds like your mother may have ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is an early stage of cancer and very treatable. Usually either lumpectomy w/ radiation or mastectomy takes care of it. Occasionally, chemo is recommended. Regardless of the type of cancer, there is treatment out there. Please try and get the final path report and come back. This place will give you so much encouragement, support and knowledge to get you both through it. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: My Mother just diagnosed with breast cancer One_person GinnyO

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 10:28AM determinedmom wrote: My bc was also found on routine mammo, not palpable at all. I did have 2 previous palpable masses, both benign. The only way to know for sure is by biopsy. Glad you're getting it checked. Best wishes, Jeanne

For what it's worth, you have a calcification cluster, not a mass which I believe means it's in the early stages, if at all. Best wishes, Jeanne

Posts.Title: just got a call to see a surgeon beergirl determinedmom

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 05:19AM determinedmom wrote: Gigi, yes you will be around for a while. I also was diagnosed w/ DCIS, 2 areas. And yes, it is cancer, very early, but cancer that can be treated. I also had cervical carcinoma in situ (again very early) about 18 yrs. ago w/ no further complications. You will get a tremendous support and encouragement here. Come back often and let us know what your path report says. There are a lot of women here who are very knowledgeable and very helpful. Sorry to hear of your mom, but glad she's doing well. Hey, if she's doing that well with bowel and liver ca, just think how you'll do. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: DCIS gigiola happy29

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2007 12:05PM determinedmom wrote: It's the right choice only if YOU feel it is best for YOU. I'm 46 and was diagnosed w/ DCIS x 2 rt. breast, one margin clear, the other w/in 1mm in May '07. Mast. was recommended since I had 2 spots. However, I was on the fence as to dbl or just the rt. I had MRI to further evaluate the other breast. The MRI was suspicious for invasive cancer, one spot each breast. That did it for me, had dbl. The final path came back all clear - no cancer, however, several areas of precancerous tissue. I did not want to have to go back for mammo, repeat mammo, US, biopsy, etc. so it was an easy decision for me. But, it was MY decision. I chose to have expanders and implants and just had my nipple reconstruction. It was a journey, one I'm glad is over. I would not have done things differently. Whatever you decide, we are all heara to support and encourage you. Get all the info you can and do what feels best for you. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice? nwsailor nwsailor

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 06:33PM determinedmom wrote: Pain meds. filled ahead of time w/ note pad and pen to keep track of what and when you take them; gauze pads, tape, stool softener and/or laxatives as pain meds will 'back you up'. Friends/family that provide dinner the 1st wk or so is a blessing and they will definitely be glad to do it. My PS also gave me muscle relaxers which definitely kept me comfortable during the whole fill process. As Jill said, listen to your body when it comes to the fills. You'll know how much you can handle and at what pace. Again, best wishes.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 06:40PM determinedmom wrote: You know how sometimes your eyes 'twitch/flutter'? I remember feeling that as well post mast w/ expanders. It didn't happen often, but was definitely weird. My bilat mast was last May and I no longer feel the sensation. Best wishes, Jeanne

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 05:12PM determinedmom wrote: You are not selfish at all. However, if you're not 100% confident w/ your decision perhaps you should postpone it until you know for sure what you want. Posts.Title: 5/9/08 date of my diagnosis Dawn08 Dawn08

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 09:23AM determinedmom wrote: Welcome Jim, you and your wife will find a ton of support and comfort here on your journey. I was dx w/ DCIS May '07, 2 sites, rt breast. I too had an MRI for further evaluation. It showed 2 areas of possible invasive ca, one each breast. Due to me having 2 sites of DCIS rt. mastectomy was recommended. Rather than dealing w/ biopsy of the suspicious sites on MRI I chose dble mastectomy w/ reconstruct. My final path report showed no further signs of cancer, however, there were a lot of precancerous areas. I am very comfortable w/ my decision as who knows at what point it would have turned into cancer and what stage it would be before it was found. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: My wife just was diagnosed with IDC jn06 Labgal

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 06:50AM determinedmom wrote: Everyone is diff. and you will get diff. responses, the main thing is listen to what your body tells you and go at your pace, not your drs. I had dble mast w/ expanders June '07, returned to wk PT just under 2 wks. later (med. sec.). I went home just under 24 hrs. after surgery. I could have stayed if I wanted to, but I was ready to get out of there. I already had my pain Rx at home. Be prepared to sleep upright for a while. I would like to make a few suggestions, button front or zip front shirts a must; pain meds. ahead of time; stool softener and/or laxatives as pain meds. can really back you up and you don't want do deal w/ that as well; friends/family willing to bring dinner for a wk or so is really nice. Again, go at your own pace and just really listen to what your body is telling you. Come back to this place often as you will receive so much encouragement and support during your journey. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: Surgery expectations Hannahbanana Hannahbanana

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2007 09:33AM determinedmom wrote: Pretty much the same experience, i had 2 needle locs. There was time inbetween the initial mammo film and inject. I had my ipod and was nice to listen to my own music to relax, luckily the radiologist doing mine was great, she had a great attitude and we joked most of the time. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 07:20AM determinedmom wrote: Definitely start stool softeners as soon as possible, may even want to have laxatives/suppositories on hand just in case. I started my softeners about 36 hrs. after surgery and ended up needing to use the suppos., don't wait too long to 'relieve' yourself. When you get your pain meds., get the easy off caps. Best wishes, Jeanne

Posts.Title: Surgery May 1st CaseyDoodle CaseyDoodle

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 07:01PM determinedmom wrote: Dawn it is a very personal decision, no one can say for sure if it will come back, when it might come back or if it will come back w/ a vengence, nothing in medicine (or life for that matter) is guaranteed. Do your research, get a second opinion if you're still not sure, even a third if it will help you. Personally, I had DCIS 2 spots last yr. in the rt breast and mast was recommended by surgeon, radiation oncologist said lumpectomy w/ rad will have same results. I elected for dbl mast w/ reconstruct due to suspicious invasive areas on MRI. Although all came out clear, I am very comfortable w/ my decision as I have 2 young boys and wanted to be around for them for a long time to come. There is another thread further down for DCIS. As Jennifer said, take a breath. No need to rush into anything unless you are absolutely certain what YOU want to do. Best wishes, Jeanne
Posts.Title: 5/9/08 date of my diagnosis Dawn08 Dawn08

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 04:28PM determinedmom wrote: Hey Dawn - I really feel for what you are going through. Every time I try to answer you I feel I will bring you more questions. Yes, you should be able to tell your surgeon ahead of time if there is cancer go ahead w/ mast. However, if you want to have reconstruction, you're going to have another procedure any way. Whereas, when I had my dbl mast I had expanders placed at the same time. That's just one type of reconstruct, there are others, but most can be done at time of mast. I do have some feeling in my breast, but not what it was before. I had previous biopsies which were negative as well as recall mammos and US. Since I had 2 areas of DCIS mast was recommended over rad mostly by my FP who I also work for and whose wife had BC, the rad. onc. thought it would end up w/ the same results if lump & rad, surgeon supported either. I was 46 and just felt my breast had served their purpose and if there was cancer, just didn't need them any more. It was a very personal decision that was supported by all those around me. Although there was no residual CA left in either breast, there was a lot of precancerous tissue and who knows at what stage it would have been found. Get all the info you can and listen to your gut, she won't let you down. Come back often, you will get so much support and comfort from this place as well as knowledge. Best wishes, Jeanne

Posts.Title: Mom just had surgery Blessed1 determinedmom

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 08:25AM determinedmom wrote: Everyone seems to have a somewhat different experience.  Although I didn't have a great deal of pain, I was very uncomfortable.  My PS gave me Robaxin + Lortab which worked great for me without making my loopy.  Also, this web site has some great stretching exercises to help: http://www.stayingabreast.com/site/browse/breathing.htm Just copy and paste.  I also found that 'walking up the wall' w/ my fingers during a gentle warm shower was a great start.  Yes, it does get easier and you can get on w/ your life.  My boys were 11 & 13 and helped out a great deal so that I didn't have to rely on others.  But you know, if they want to help let them.  I'm sure you would do the same for them.  Good luck at your appt.  Best wishes, Jeanne
